channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 29 April
item.description: Just two new cases of Covid-19 confirmed, Winston Peters' revealed the health ministry wanted closed borders, and the Epidemic Response Committee hears from medical practitioners.

item.title: Cycling popularity changes gear during lockdown and supporters look to capitalise
item.description: A survey has shown cycling was a popular new form of exercise during the lockdown, and people are now arguing for improved bike infrastructure.

item.title: Schools, ECEs reopen with fewer children than expected
item.description: Schools and ECEs reopened today for the first time in five weeks, but less than half the expected pupils attended.

item.title: Air NZ crews hoping to halt redundancies until alert level 2
item.description: Air NZ is facing an escalating stoush over plans to lay off hundreds of flight attendants, while many are worried the company is not doing enough to curb the risks of spreading Covid-19.

item.title: Fiordland tourism operators frustrated with national park rules
item.description: Fiordland tourism operators say the rules governing the national park are outdated and leave no room for common sense.

item.title: Covid-19: A question about false negatives
item.description: Most of the audience questions we have answered during this Covid-19 madness have been straightforward, but sometimes one is not so easy to answer, writes Glen Scanlon.

item.title: Sisters denied request to visit dying mother
item.description: Two sisters battling to get out of mandatory quarantine early to see their dying mother have had their appeal denied.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world
item.description: There were 742 complaints of businesses not complying with the rules on the first day of alert level 3. See how the rest of the day's events unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Two new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand
item.description: There have been just two new cases of Covid-19 reported in the past 24 hours, the Health Ministry has revealed.

item.title: TradeMe searches show Kiwis keen to learn new skills in level 3
item.description: Now that we're out of lockdown, New Zealanders are suddenly buying musical instruments, and thinking of purchasing a mountain bike says TradeMe.

item.title: Stolen Jucy rental cars left unlocked with keys inside, police say
item.description: The 112 Jucy rental cars stolen by "opportunists" were left unlocked in a yard - so far, only 69 have been recovered.

item.title: Covid-19: 'New Zealand's response has been one of the strongest' - WHO
item.description: The World Health Organisation says New Zealand has been world-leading in its response to Covid-19. But at the same time, a top official for the organisation is warning against complacency.

item.title: Sisters appeal for isolation exemption to see dying mother
item.description: Two sisters who have flown from Melbourne to be with their dying mother are asking for an exemption so they can leave quarantine early, but say the process has been unwieldy and slow.

item.title: Man accused of coughing at woman charged
item.description: A 21-year-old man accused of coughing at a woman out walking in Alexandra has been arrested.

item.title: Two thirds of renters struggling, says new report
item.description: A survey of almost 2000 tenants by Renters United shows that two thirds had lost at least a third of their income under lockdown and 92 percent of those with reduced incomes were still paying full rent.

item.title: Whakaari/White Island rocks may hold clues to eruption risk - research
item.description: Unique, cracked rocks on Whakaari/White Island allow gas to escape, easing the build-up of pressure that triggers volcanic eruptions, but can become clogged and act like valves.

item.title: Southern DHB 'confident' transmission from Bluff cluster stopped
item.description: One of the country's worst-hit regions for Covid-19 is confident it has turned a corner. There are just 14 active cases in the Southern DHB compared with 101 a couple of weeks ago.

item.title: Wellingtonians 'amped' to return to work in level 3
item.description: Wellington locals say they are excited to get back to work while ensuring that 2-metre distance.
